42.93.text:
Good afternoon, everyone, thank you for joining
you go today. If this is your first time

47.59.text:
joining us KSOC stands for knowledge network
for systems of care. I'm Gary Blau chief of

55.73.text:
child adolescent and family branch of the
substance abuse and Mental Health Services

60.22.text:
Administration. SAMHSA. KSOC-TV provides training
and technical assistance related to

67.46.text:
the needs of children, youth and families.
Our first webisode titled role of psychotropic

74.07.text:
medication in children 
with four [ new live webisodes covering topics
such as youth and

88.31.text:
young adults, trauma informed care, and supporting
families who have LGBT youth. Today

we're going to further explore the topic we
introduced on national children's mental

100.94.text:
health Awareness Day in May. The mental health
needs of young adults. Our discussion

107.33.text:
today will focus specifically on how we can
help young active duty military personnel,

114.28.text:
young veterans, and young parents deal with
challenges specific to their experiences.

121.56.text:
Throughout today's program, we encourage you
to join the conversation by tweeting

126.32.text:
questions to #KSOC-TV, click being the ask
a question icon just above your screen, or

136.64.text:
calling 1-800-527-1401. Great panel today
representing different perspectives on these

148.38.text:
issues. Please welcome Aidan Bohlander from

157.81.text:
Warriors. And Jim Saintgermain from Preparing
Leaders For Tomorrow who is also a young

166.09.text:
parent and has experienced his own behavioral
health problems. Before we start our

173.52.text:
conversation today, though, let's check in
on what's happening in children's mental health

178.38.text:
and systems of care. Stephanie Dukes is at
our news desks with the latest headlines.

184.94.text:
>> I'm Stephanie Dukes. Here are our top stairs.
In May New York City first daughter

192.28.text:
Chiara de Blasio was recognized bit substance
abuse and mental health services

197.43.text:
administration for her positive messages encouraging
young adults with mental and

202.43.text:
is because use intordz to seek peer support.
She received a special from U.S. Department

209.81.text:
of Health and Human Services secretary Kathleen
Sebelius in Washington, D.C.. hundreds of

218.98.text:
local communities also took part in Awareness
Day interface activities. Texas system of

224.67.text:
care of collaborated with the Texas Department
of State Health Services to engage

229.96.text:
communities throughout the state for Awareness
Day. Activities included a one mile walk,

235.66.text:
a kite flying ceremony, and a proclamation
at the Austin City Hall. The Alamance Alliance

242.34.text:
For Children and Families in North Carolina
presented a workshop at the National

247.00.text:
Smart Start Conference in Greensboro. This
social marketing project uses art and film

254.44.text:
start a dialogue around children's social
and emotional health. Across the country in

260.55.text:
Mexico, the Pueblo of San Felipe conducted
school presentations, hosted a community talent

266.94.text:
show and offered a parent information session
on the effects of substance abuse on

272.06.text:
children. And finally, the Guam Behavioral
Health and wellness center celebrated

276.88.text:
Awareness Day with an Art of Healing contest
in schools and a proclamation signing with

282.72.text:
Governor Eddie Calvo. The largest study of
mental health and resilience ever conducted

288.97.text:
among U.S. military personnel released its
first findings recently. This was an effort

295.13.text:
help behavioral health experts better understand
suicide risk and ultimately improve

300.52.text:
protective factors among this population.
Nearly 85 percent of soldier who self-identify

306.79.text:
as having a mental health disorder reported
the problem began prior tone listing and

312.35.text:
approximately 30 percent of post enlistment
suicide attempts tied back to pre enlistment

318.90.text:
mental disorders. The study also suggests
there's a correlation between soldiers demotion

325.22.text:
and suicide risk and there is an increased
risk in soldiers who did not hold at least

330.43.text:
high school diploma or GED. According to the
data, military personnel at highest risk of

336.78.text:
suicide are white, male, or junior enlisted
rank. In the state of Maryland the majors

344.14.text:
adults initiative has shown improved outcomes
for transitioning young adults with mental

349.02.text:
health and co-occurring disorders. Of the
50 young adults who are actively participating

354.34.text:
in the program, 18 had currently employed,
nine live independently and eight are attending

360.65.text:
community college. The emerging adults initiative
is a cross-agency initiative aimed at

366.49.text:
addressing issues that youth and young adults
encounter as they transition into adulthood.

371.85.text:
Finally, some promising news about the peer
support as a mental health strategy.

376.95.text:
According to the research and training center
for pathways to positive futures, which is

382.33.text:
co-funded by SAMHSA and the national institute
on disability and rehabilitatio research,

388.64.text:
one to one peer support among individuals
who have co-occurring mental health and

392.97.text:
substance abuse disorders was found to result
in fewer hospitalizations, improved social

398.76.text:
functioning, reduced substance use and improved
quality of life among participants.

404.61.text:
Research also shows that peer support plays
a part in reducing the overall need for mental

409.97.text: health services over time. Back to you. Gary.

415.16.text:
>> Gary Blau: Thanks, Stephanie. Now let's
turn to our panel. Today we'll be discussing

421.51.text:
the unique mental health needs of young adults
who are currently serving in the military,

those who have already served, those who are
parents, as well as young military service

members who also happen to be parents. I'd

captain finch. Tell us a little bit about

>> Captain Finch: Certainly, Gary. First let

460.61.text:

that every individual has a unique decision
in terms of when they seek care. The

492.27.text:
we certainly want to encourage those who feel
that they are having some psychological

health concerns to reach out for care as soon

of resources that are available to service
members as well as the families because what

we've learned is that it's typically the family

514.28.text: some type of support or assistance to the

servicemen so we want to the make sure our
service members and their family members really

understand what are some of the issues
related to psychological health. What are

to combat stress. That's the first step. Once
they're able to do that, they're definitely

welcome to contact our defense centers of

of resources to assist them in discerning

needs

569.61.text:
>> Gary Blau: Can you talk more about what

active or veteran in terms of what their

582.59.text:
stresses are?
>> Captain Finch: Certainly. One of the things

585.23.text: we want the audience to recognize is that

587.77.text:
oftentimes service members when they return
home, it can be a stressful time for them

594.28.text:
they reintegrate. We don't want to increase
the concern that may be existing but we want

604.15.text:
to be realistic and truly understand what
combat stress concerns may exist. Typically

611.81.text:
we
may find our service member struggling with

614.73.text:
readjustment, with the time, with family,
getting used to the routines or finding that

622.97.text:
they're frustrated in dealing with what may
appear to us to be small situations. It may

be a pretty big deal for service members.
So

632.17.text:
we want to be sensitive to and understanding
their needs. And so we encourage the family

638.68.text:
members to find out when they speak with the
service member or loved one who's returning

642.93.text:
home, find out what they need. Talk to them.
Find out how they're feeling. Let them

647.69.text:
know that you care about them and that you're
concerned and that you're there to assist.

653.17.text:
But we also want our audience to understand
that take your time in working with the

661.03.text:
service member or the veteran in helping them
to reunite with their family or even

665.41.text:
within their community. Talk with them, find
out what their needs are. It's okay to

673.21.text:
begin to establish some of the routines that

such as normal family outings, spending time
together.

683.19.text:
>> Part of this idea of reintegration and

live at least some of these mental health

member or veteran and they believe that individual

>> Gary Blau: That's great. I'm hoping we

get that number up on the screen a lot

show everyone now a video clip of a young

the

video, please. (Video)
>> My name is campaign Joshua Mantz and I've

791.17.text:
been in the military for five years. I was
deployed to Iraq from October 2006 to January

797.66.text:
of 2008. Josh was injured
in Sadr City. He and his platoon sergeant

803.00.text:
why standing side by side and a bullet
ricocheted through that sergeant into Josh's

808.08.text:
leg and that's the core of what happened in
that incident where one soldier was lost but

813.44.text:
Josh was able to survive. It's not just
those with visible wounds. It's everybody

817.78.text:
else in that small unit that was part of that
action. That's a part of that have soldier's

821.87.text:
life that are affected as well. We have
critical stress debriefing teams, and when

827.98.text:
something like what happened to Josh occurs,
we

830.38.text:
make everybody come together and tell that
story. Oftentimes what happens is you walk

835.75.text:
away from a moment in combat and you remember
it like you saw it. When you come together

840.62.text:
as a team and someone mediates the story and
helps you put it all together, you learn the

845.83.text:
rest of the story and it makes it easier to
balance what really happened, what your role

849.68.text:
was in it, what you were and were not responsible
for and you don't go by the way from

853.22.text:
that moment and create your own story in your
mind, and go on feeling guilty or anxious

858.23.text:
or
otherwise. And that doesn't have to end right

861.05.text:
there. That kind of help, that kind of
group discussion, group therapy, or otherwise,

867.34.text:
can facilitate the ability of a soldier to
come back from a combat trauma at any time.

>> Gary Blau: That's great. I also wanted

kind of social networks you talk talked about

946.70.text:
Again the outreach center, but then there's

individuals in contact with a variety of other

necessarily be combat stress related, but

considered to be helpful to families as they

One of the other resources that I'm sure our

of

And because we know the family members are

care or some of the other needs associated

again, that number is 1-866-966-1020 provide

1044.30.text:
>> Gary Blau: All of the resources are pretty

there are resources for vets as they come

vets to success program, for example, and

different branches of our military really

1067.16.text:
here to make sure that we provide as many

1074.99.text:
do appreciate that. I'd like to turn our discussion
right now to the mental health needs

1082.61.text:
of young parents. And we're very happy today
to be able to have Aidan Bohlander with us.

1090.97.text:
One of the things that we're hearing is that
young parents, veterans, and, have a lot of

1097.65.text:
different kinds of stressors and issues like
this, and I'm wondering if you can talk

1102.33.text:
a little bit more about what some of the issues
that you're finding in your work around

1107.71.text:
the zero to three and young parents that you
see around those kinds of issues.

1113.17.text:
>> Sure. I think one of the things we need
to acknowledge first is that parenting in

1117.99.text:
general can be extremely, very rewarding but
can be very stressful. I once heard it

1123.31.text:
described by a parent as going -- waking up
one morning and finding out that you have

1133.37.text:
been
chosen as the leader of a new country and

1136.51.text:
you don't know the language and you don't
know

1138.18.text:
the customs and you don't know the geography.
But everybody is looking to you to

1144.08.text:
intuitively know how to do this, how to be
this leader. So parenting in general can be

1150.25.text:
overwhelming. When you add in the stressors
of being a young parent, somebody emerging

1155.21.text:
from a very egocentric time of their life,
they're being asked to care for a young child,

1163.97.text:
that's a tough transition to make. Another
thing we know about very young parents is

1169.43.text:
that
they have very young children. And those children,

1178.01.text:
we know we have a big body of research
that tells us that early experiences matter

1183.73.text:
for very young children. So we know that
this is kind of a crux. You have very young

1189.40.text:
parents who are emerging of this time of
thinking about themselves to now needing to

1194.13.text:
focus on a child who has high needs in order
to get on a good developmental trajectory.

1201.19.text:
So we have some special considerations to
make. Layer on top of that maybe having some

1206.18.text:
mental health challenges where you're
feeling overwhelmed, maybe panicked. You can

1213.10.text:
really up the stressor here. We know for
young parents with mental health challenges,

1218.09.text:
they're more likely to have financial
instability, experience unemployment, and

1223.15.text:
have relationship instability when we know
that

1226.05.text:
support is what they really need. So lots
of issues here with young parents with mental

1231.87.text:
health challenges. But the good news is we
do know some information about supporting

1236.88.text:
them.
>> Gary Blau: That's awesome. And can you

1240.68.text:
describe a little bit about what your

things we know is that very young children

And one of the things we have on our website

to

>> Gary Blau: That website you spell that

>> Gary Blau: I say that to make sure our

explained, that when parents are experiencing,

to

>> I definitely was experienced mental health

1364.57.text:
challenges. I've struggled with
mental health challenges practically my entire

1369.09.text:
life especially during my teenage years.
They were very difficult. I struggled from

1376.24.text:
anxiety disorder and a bunch of other
diagnoses but my anxiety is the worst. It

1382.41.text:
was definitely challenging and there were
a lot

1386.57.text:
of ups and downs. But it's also very enlightening
and you learn a lot about yourself.

1391.11.text:
When I found out I was pregnant, it was a
very scary time for me because the father

1400.10.text:
of my
child was very abusive and I was experiencing

1404.72.text:
a lot of domestic violence which really

myself. That made it really difficult,
especially coming out of that situation and

1423.49.text:

1430.23.text:

too, because it gave you an understanding
of

1438.15.text:

the

State. So sharing your story and personal

I would definitely share my past experiences,
the lessons I've learned, both good and bad,

1467.27.text:
to help that individual step from that place

1473.59.text:
through those steps in a way that people helped

>> Gary Blau: I'd like it on focus on the

a
moment. For those who have previously been

about anxieties that could negatively affect

one of the questions that people might have
is

prior to giving birth, how can these young

effective environment, stimulating environment.

best

practice would tell us is that there are particular

1549.65.text:
you would like to have the person engage in,
the young person engage in before they have

1554.02.text:
the child and then also talking about what
it's going to be like to be a parent, that

1559.26.text:
this

1562.28.text:

about what it's going to be like to be a parent

1586.50.text:
that they're going to be caring for somebody

that time. And thankful will you she was
able to do so

>> Gary Blau: What kinds of tools or programs

>> Well, we're trying to build systems care

1603.91.text:
across the United States. We spend time

would recommend to young parents is looking
up

1613.44.text:
in this online generation a peer support network

1618.96.text:
Elizabeth participated in. Young parents really
like to engage with people who have gone

1626.15.text:
before them and who they can relate to. I

1631.16.text:
their
favorite search engine to look for peer support

1633.45.text:
network. Also, you're going to be
engaging probably with somebody who will be

1638.13.text:
caring for concur child whether it's a
grandmother or early care and education provider,

1642.88.text:
and asking those folks about resources
in the area for support and education.

1646.85.text:
>> Gary Blau: Wonderful. I'm going to turn

to some of the challenges that we heard from

1660.32.text:
>> Certainly can relate. For me growing up

1665.82.text:
with hardships and depression and educational
challenges and educational disabilities and

1674.66.text:
a lot of traumas and violence, that affected
me as a young man. As a matter of fact, I

1680.67.text:
believe it was one of the reasons that got
me into the juvenile justice system where

1685.25.text:
I
spent three and a half years and it's important

1688.66.text:
to provide services to these young
people. Mentoring and other services through

1694.94.text:
the the community to help them becomes the
best of themselves they can become. And mentoring

1704.16.text:
and peer support is one of -- two
of the best ways to get that work done in

1708.46.text:
helping these young people out.
>> Gary Blau: When you talk about peer support,

1715.02.text:
and this kind of mentoring, can you
elaborate on that a little bit so people who

1719.22.text:
may not have that background can better
understand?

1723.17.text:
>> One thing we know is that young people
most of the time, it's really easier to help

1729.17.text:
a
young person who's been through the same circumstances

1731.78.text:
that you've been. So if I've belt
with justify justice issues and mental health

1736.21.text:
and substance abuse and I know that there's
a person out there who's walked that spath

1740.71.text:
and has been trained to
provide emotional, social, knowledge and practical

1746.65.text:
experiences to me who's been trained by
a particular organization to do that, then

1751.25.text:
that's something that can be really important
and extremely significant to helping our young

1754.70.text:
people out. And that's what peer support
does. There's a person who's walked down that

1759.63.text:
same path that you're currently walking on,
trained to provide services to you and be

1764.73.text:
that support for you and let you know that
I've

1767.52.text:
been down that path and it's going to be all
right and I'm here to support you because,

1771.03.text:
again, I've walked your path
>> Gary Blau: Can you share a little bit about

1776.00.text:
the kind of peer support or the way in
which that folks have helped you that you

1781.51.text:
have found to be successful?
>> For me, I've had a lost mentors and a lot

1786.59.text:
of peer supporters who have looked out for
me to make sure I was on the right path and

1792.08.text:
I was taken seriously, staying out of
trouble. I was basically doing what I needed

1797.47.text:
to do. Those mentors can basically pave the
way for you and show you a different side

1802.71.text:
of life that perhaps you're not used to seeing.
When you're going through hardships sometimes

1806.91.text:
you tend to think that, look, I'm the only
one that's dealing with this and the world

1811.03.text:
is collapsing around me. And sometimes you
speak to a spear supporter and you get to

1815.85.text:
realize that it's not true. There are or people
who are dealing with these same issues. And

1821.37.text:
you get together with them and build
relationships it will be much more helpful.

1825.30.text:
I've had that as a young person which is now
I'm app strong advocate for peer support and

1830.91.text:
also mentoring organizations that can provide
services and help our young people.

1835.04.text:
>> Gary Blau: At the same time that you're
doing all of this, I understand that you,

1840.50.text:
>> Yes.
>> Gary Blau: Of an almost one year-old. Very,

1845.23.text:
very cool. Can you talk about that
a little bit?

1847.66.text:
>> , yes, sir, my son, who's everything that
I live for now, he'll be one on Friday. He's

1855.57.text:
very energetic and he's given me a lot of
work to do on top of all the work that I have

1860.35.text:
to do outside of the home. It's not easy being
a young parent. As Aidan talked about,

1866.59.text:
you're still in that stage where it's all
about yourself. I want to take care of yourself

1872.20.text:
and go out and do certain things but you have
a young child to care for. So you have to

1878.29.text:
understand that it's time to put yourself
to the side a little bit and make sure you

1883.67.text:
take
care of this young person because there's

1885.51.text:
no better job and more critical job than raising
a young mind. So that's what I've been doing.

1893.89.text:
It's been an awesome experience for me so
far

1896.27.text:
>> Gary Blau: And I think one of the things

1903.25.text:
of your resilience is to hear a little bit

1907.80.text:
of
the juvenile justice system. And that through

Can you talk a little bit about getting
back on the right track?

1921.17.text:
>> So after spending approximately three and
a half years in the juvenile justice system,

1925.71.text:
back in New York City, I've had mentors in

1935.17.text:

to support me when I left the juvenile justice

1940.98.text:

are market and got my GED and got back to

1947.14.text:
school. I went to college where I graduated
with an associate's degree in human services,

1952.99.text:
I wanted to go into social work. And then
I advanced and went to college where I

1957.49.text:
graduated with a bachelor's in political science.
Right now I'm currently attending NYU

1962.54.text:
Wagner for one service, getting a masters
in public administration and not for profit

1967.92.text:
so
I can run a not for profit that provides services

1971.65.text:
to at risk young, young people deeming
with the same circumstances I dealt with and

1976.82.text:
so many of the young people I'm working with

1980.68.text:
that I work with on a regular basis who are

1984.99.text:
and I want to be able to provide those

1989.89.text:
using all my connections and experiences to
be the best that I can be in that particular

1994.73.text:
area.
>> Gary Blau: That's a remarkable story, Jim.

1998.83.text:
I think we're all proud of you. Also a

member what we're trying to promote through

sources. [

>> Gary Blau: I think if there's any indication

2349.20.text:
are developing. We actually had a question
coming in on our twit are feed here and I

2355.14.text:
think it may be something for all of you.
It's what is the best way to approach a person

2361.91.text:
and this could be a young parent or an individual

2368.31.text:

>> Start with a quote. Frederick Douglas said

2378.09.text:
children do not care how much you know
until they know how much you care. So meaning

2383.28.text:
that when you're approaching young people
or someone who seems that they need help first

2388.64.text:
you have to show them you care about them,
that you do that by listening to them and

2393.31.text:
by paying attention to what they're doing,
engaging them. Once they know you care then

2398.02.text:
it will be easier for them to allow you in
their lives. Then you guest the chance to

2401.70.text:
help them. If not, you'll never get
an opportunity to really help them until you

2405.51.text:
can prove that I really care about you.
That's why I'm here

2410.23.text:
>> We have a number of strategies on our addressing
this. Really coming from a place of

2420.75.text:
wondering and being non-judgmental. So I'm
just wondering, I'm seeing that you're really

2428.48.text:
sleepy at work or when you're dropping concur
child off at child care. And I'm

2433.70.text:
just wondering what's going on. I'm just concerned
about you. And leaving it at that and

letting the person kind of come to you, using
your observations and an open mind to let

2444.20.text:
the person start talking to you about where
they're at. But really starting the

2448.93.text:
conversation is the important piece. And not
letting that moment pass by

2453.22.text:
>> It can be hard to start that conversation.
Talking to people about mental health and

2459.69.text:
substance abuse issues can be uncomfortable.
Do you have any ideas or thoughts for folks

2466.17.text:
about how to deal with your own discomfort

2469.92.text:
>> Yeah, it can be very uncomfortable to talk

2475.61.text:
have brought up. But what I would say to you
is your level of discomforted is telling you

2481.22.text:
there's an issue at hand. And to really listen
to that. And just to be careful in your

2488.09.text:
approach. As a social worker I have to say
safety first but really coming at that from

2493.92.text:
a
place of being non-judgmental and I love the

2497.03.text:
phrase I'm wondering. I'm wondering.
>> And I think finding one thing that you

2502.87.text:
have in common with that person. For example,
I learned about some of the things that they

2509.46.text:
like. If Johnny likes basketball or if he
likes football or this one likes working out

I get engaged and invite Johnny to the gym
or

2518.19.text:
perhaps I talk to him about basketball or
football. Take him to the park. Play a game

2522.25.text:
with him. And then that breaks the ice and
we can get into the real work

2526.16.text:
>> I want to echo a lot of what they both
said. I think this is this notion of engaging

2533.43.text:
the individual. Again, starting where that
person is and not being judgmental. Those

are the two most important aspects of the

2547.83.text:
How are you feeling? And maybe sometimes that

into perspective to be able to open up. The

2558.55.text:
discussion is not giving up. Again, the notion

encourage that level of engagement.
>> You have to think when a person is dealing

with certain issues, dealt with a lot of

2579.85.text:
their lives. And when you try to approach

like geez, another one coming in and trying

I'm
not just a person who's coming in to kind

of find out about you and walk out. You want
to

show them that you're going to be there, you
wanted to be consistent and committed to

2599.31.text:
whatever it is that they need. They're not

2603.85.text:
>> We know from, again, robust body of research

2609.35.text:
relationships matter. So you have to make

going to be able to affect real change
>> When we tell people about, say, the success

of things, and it depends of course on your

on and there are places to look at, particularly

mental health challenges we have things

then how the past, the parent's past experience

read the child's cues and behaviors because

2683.13.text:
behavior has meaning for children. So there's

2688.49.text:
practices
>> The Real Warriors campaign has obviously

the

it

large who care about those who sacrifice so

some questions here through the Twitter feed

with

that we can inform individuals about psyche

being aware and being agent encourage

2939.74.text:

2945.59.text:
not
have a psychological health concern to come

the way, we're only talking about a small

issue, all of these things are connected.

3017.65.text:

down those kinds of barriers. One thing, Jim,

3220.46.text:
I would follow up with you, young people
themselves tend to have, whether it's a fearfulness

3227.20.text:
or concern, about disclosing these
kinds of issues. And in terms of captain finch

3234.31.text:
was saying, what would you say to a young
person around their concerns related to be

3239.42.text:
discriminated against if they share a
mental health challenge?

3244.74.text:
>>,
young people not want to go reveal some of

3247.55.text:
the issues and mental health difficulties
that they're facing makes sense to me, as

3252.06.text:
a young
person you're being teased by other kids who

3254.83.text:
don't really the importance of seeking
services and health. They call you retarded

3260.05.text:
or slow. Use these terms freely. So for a
young person that can really hurt you. So

3267.43.text:
you don't want your peers to know you're
struggling with certain issues. I think for

3272.09.text:
me I would tell a young person that tts
all right to embrace your challenges because

3277.55.text:
your challenges eventually are going to make
you better. You need to seek services and

3284.98.text:
that everyone in society deals with certain
circumstances, perhaps it's not mental health,

3290.13.text:
but maybe something else. That it's okay
and you have to embrace them and we have to

3295.00.text:
seek help and we have to seek support and
assistance from others and that's the only

3300.47.text:
way we're going to move forward and get
better. As I said, I've dealt with a lot of

3305.67.text:
these challenges. I couldn't read and my
attention span is really short. Still is to

3312.68.text:
this day. I've dealt with some of these
challenges. If you embrace it and look for

3320.46.text:
the help and have the positive peer support
around you, you can get over the hump and

3327.16.text:
you can break those barriers
>> Gary Blau: Jim, one of our media site questions

3332.70.text:
came in for you asking if you can
share some examples of how your family and

3337.50.text:
friends have supported you specifically around
parenting your son.

3343.08.text:
>> Well, I have most of my friends are older
than I am. And I'll tell you, I used to

3350.79.text:
babysit for a lot of them. And some of them
I still go to their houses and eat up all

3355.02.text:
their food in the refrigerator. I bring my
son over and I'll just watch them and see

3359.97.text:
how
they parent their children. I'm a really great

3362.91.text:
learner when it comes to watching people.
Not just them telling me in terms of some

3369.59.text:
of the things I need to do, being patient
and

3372.07.text:
following through with my son and staying
consistent and all the important things he's

3378.45.text:
going to need in order to become successful.
But I really watched my friends and they've

3383.75.text:
given me great feedback and telling me to
stay committed and understand that I'm not

3389.45.text:
the
primary focus anymore, that my son is, that

3393.00.text:
it's okay to take a back seat and just watch
him grow and be there for him. That feedback

3399.40.text:
and constructive criticism have been really
helpful for me as a young parent although

3403.85.text:
I must say that his mother actually, as we
know,

3408.02.text:
all the ladies on the panel know, does most
of the work. So --

3412.34.text:
>> Gary Blau: I'm glad that you're honest
about that. In my family we'd be honest about

3419.47.text:
that too.
>> I think that is consistent. Jim brings

3421.85.text:
up a beautiful point that we have
an opportunity when we work with young people

3427.55.text:
and young parents to affect not just that
generation but the next generation. These

3433.40.text:
early experiences such as your son is having
with you that are very positive because you've

3439.47.text:
been able to address them as your
challenges and you're willing to work on them

3443.36.text:
are going to pay dividends for your child.
So when we think about investing our dollars

3450.70.text:
and resources, whether they be with military
families or young parents experiencing mental

3456.26.text:
health challenges or just parents in
general, we know that investing in the parent

3463.06.text:
really pays dividends in working for the
child in the next generation.

3467.30.text:
>> The department has focused own a number
of programs such as the yellowish ribbons

3472.90.text:
program which provides support to National
Guard reserves in the community. And many

3478.92.text:
of
their events are also designed for spouse

3482.05.text:
and is children so the entire family gets
support

3485.88.text:
>> Gary Blau: We have about 30 seconds left.
Wanda, what should we tell a young person

3493.89.text:
if they have mental health challenges about
considering a career in the military

3497.10.text:
>> Captain Finch: I think they need to consider
whether or not that's going to be the

3503.75.text:
career path for them. And if so, I would encourage
them, if they are a child of a

3510.05.text:
military service member or veteran, to take
advantage of some of the yellowish ribbon

3515.62.text:
events and also joining forces initiative
led by the first lady and Dr. Biden. They

3523.05.text:
also
have a number of programs under their umbrella

3526.11.text:
that also work with families. And so
I think that those are some unique opportunities

3531.27.text:
that can exist right there in everyone's
back yard, take an opportunity, visit. Find

3536.78.text:
out how these programs can support you if
you are considering that type of career. Again,

3543.47.text:
it's a personal decision for those who
choose to go down that path.

3548.14.text:
>> Gary Blau: Well, I'm sort of just amazed
at the wealth of knowledge and the

3553.42.text:
information and Real Warriors program and
the information you provided and the yellow

3560.02.text:
rib
button program. Jim, I can't wait to vote

3565.53.text:
for you for something. To see such young
leadership, it's heartening to many of us.

3575.51.text:
It should also provide a sense of support
to

3579.83.text:
those who may experience problems and issues
to say that there is a light at the end of

3585.38.text:
the tunnel and people who want to support.
I think the work of zero to three is

3590.39.text:
remarkable. So I'd like to thank our panelists
again for taking part in today's KSOC-TV

3597.78.text:
webisode. We're so glad you could join us
and participate. I want folks to please stand

3604.95.text:
by for a list of additional resources that
you can use to help support our young veterans

3610.83.text:
and our young parents. Also hope that you
can join us on July 17th for our next webisode

3618.17.text:
which will occur live from the Georgetown
training institute. I want to thank everyone

3623.91.text:
once again and the crew and back stage people
too. Thank you for watching KSOC-TV.
